title: Who is responsible for providing me Satisfaction of Judgment (Form EJ-100)?
question: I know that the judgment creditor is responsible, but which one?? It's 2015, and I still haven't gotten a satisfaction of judgment.
answers: In California, a Satisfaction of Judgment form is filed by the judgment creditor once the judgment creditor is paid the outstanding debt. The judgment creditor is generally represented by an attorney. Sometimes, judgment creditors' attorney is a member of a larger firm. Within that firm, there may be multiple attorneys that work on any particular case. If the two attorneys are a part of the same firm, just contact the firm and ask to speak with either of the two attorneys. If the two attorneys are from different firms, then what likely happened is that one was hired by the judgment creditor to file the lawsuit and see it through to judgment, and then once that was completed, and an Abstract was obtained and recorded in the counties in which you own property, the judgment creditor was passed off to a judgment collections firm - with whom you settled with. If the two are from different firms, this is likely the reason why, and in such a case, you should contact the second attorney (that you settled with), and request a satisfaction of judgment.

As a practical matter I would contact both attorneys. There is a Judicial Council Form called Acknowledgment of Satisfaction of Judgment which the judgment creditor of record is supposed to supply to you filled in and signed for you to file with the court and record, if a necessary.

If the judgment has been fully or partly satisfied, then send a written demand to file a full or partial satisfaction of judgment and send them a prepared copy of the satisfaction that you want them to file with the court. If fully satisfied, you also should get a notarized original or a certified copy from the clerk to record with the county clerk/recorder's office. Any problems, hire a debt collection DEFENSE attorney to handle this for you and make the correct demands to the collection attorney.

The party, not either attorney. The attorneys are only representatives of the party. If you said the amount necessary to satisfy the judgment, demand that the creditor file a Satisfaction of Judgment. If the creditor fails or refuses, you can file a motion with the court. You might be able to recover your attorney's fees.
Without knowing why settlement was with a second party, it's difficult to say. You need an attorney to look at what happened and then to get the satisfaction. Try limited scope representation.
